p.text: [p class="inlineImage" data-img="0"][/p] [p]You are Jaimie, a young villager with a love for the enchanted forest that everyone else fears. Will you find the secret power that now rules Castle Pentegarn?[/p] [p]The paths you may take beyond the pillars are many, and the choices are yours. Only you can decide whether the wizard Pentegarn regains his kingdom![/p] [p]Will you fight the dragon skeleton with the brave fighter Baltek at your side?[/p] [p]Will you try to trick the evil master whose slaves control castle Pentegarn?[/p] [p]Or will you run down a passage into the unknown, followed by the lovely elven thief, Lydia?[/p] [p]No matter which choices you make, adventure and action are yours in ENDLESS QUEST™ books. You will find yourself returning again and again to experience new paths of excitement.[/p] [p]Will YOUR choices halt the rule of evil in the PILLARS OF PENTEGARN?[/p]

[p]A scaly, bark-covered hand wraps its long thin fingers around your shoulder. A wispy voice whispers, “Excuse me, friend. I need to tidy up around you.”[/p] [p]Your friend Tree lowers a branch and you climb on eagerly. You are always happy to rest in Tree’s branches and watch your friends scurry about the forest.[/p] [p]You are Jaimie, a young villager living at the edge of a mysterious forest. Although the people of your village tell tales of woodland terrors and ferocious beasts lurking in these woods, you have spent your happiest moments rambling through the forest, climbing Tree’s craggy trunk, and playing with your friends, Fox and Owl.[/p] [p]While Tree’s leafy fingers straighten flower stems and brush his knobby roots, you listen to him discuss a party of adventurers with Fox and Owl.[/p] [p]“I thought them an exceptional group,” Tree says. “When they built their campfire, they gathered only dead wood. They did not break any of my branches, nor did they carve my bark. When they left, they put out their fire and cleaned their campsite.”[/p]

[p]“Well, I think they’re heading for trouble,” says Fox. “I followed them when they left this morning. They went off toward the river, but then they back-tracked and started toward the Pillars of Pentegarn!”[/p] [p]Owl gasps, “The Pillars of Pentegarn! Surely, you are mistaken!”[/p] [p]“No way, birdbrain,” Fox snaps. “Do you think I have this nose for nothing? I can track anything, and their little tricks aren’t going to fool me. If I say they were going to the Pillars of Pentegarn, that’s where they were going!”[/p] [p]There is a long silence. The Pillars of Pentegarn lie in the most frightening part of the forest. N ot even the bravest creatures go there.[/p] [p]“Hide!” Tree says suddenly. “Fast! I see goblins coming up the path!”[/p] [p]You jump down and skitter under a bush. Owl flutters high into Tree’s branches. Fox hides behind a rock, then changes his mind and runs for the forest. He is in plain sight when the goblins march into the clearing.[/p] [p]Without pausing, the goblins throw their spears at Fox. He yelps and runs into the bushes. The spears miss him, but they thud solidly into Tree, whose breeze-like groans pass unheard by the monsters.[/p] [p]“Missed!” grunts one.[/p]

[p]“Doesn’t matter. Fox taste bad,” answers another.[/p] [p]“Don’t care about taste. Hunting is funnest part.”[/p] [p]The largest goblin rips its spear out of Tree, then drops to all fours and sniffs the ground. “Girl’s scarf,” it says, picking up a white kerchief. “They been here. Close now.”[/p] [p]The goblins crowd around their leader, pushing and shoving each other. Finally, the largest goblin pushes its way out of the crowd and runs down the trail toward the river. The others follow quickly.[/p] [p]When the last goblin pounds down the path, you scurry out from beneath your bush and rush to Tree. He moans softly and his branches sway in pain.[/p] [p]You inspect the wounds and plug them with wet, clean moss. The flow of sap slowly stops. Tree has calmed, and only an occasional movement of his branches tells you he suffers great pain.[/p] [p]Owl climbs down as soon as you finish patching Tree’s trunk. A goblin spear has pierced his left wing. “Do not be overly concerned,” gasps Owl. “They just winged me.” You remove the spear and carefully press a pad of moss onto the wound.[/p] [p class="inlineImage" data-img="4"][/p]

[p]Fox returns and inspects his wounded friends. “Wow! Can you imagine what they’ll do to those adventurers?” he asks.[/p] [p]“I don’t want to think about it,” you say.[/p] [p]“But you must!” urges Tree. “If we don’t warn them, they won’t stand a chance. We must do something!”[/p] [p]“Don’t look at me, I can’t warn them,” Fox says. “You’re the only human I’m on speaking terms with.”[/p] [p]“Fox is correct,” Owl says. “You are the only human I have ever met who talks to animals. It would be useless for Fox or myself to attempt to warn the adventurers, for they would not understand us. You must warn them, Jaimie.”[/p]
p.next: Warn the adventurers of their danger
Or return home, deciding you are too frightened to risk meeting the goblins again

p.text: [p]“Let Baltek do what he does best – fight!” you say. “Let’s go straight to the tower. The longer we sneak around, the more likely we are to get caught.”[/p] [p]Pentegarn looks at you sadly for a long moment. You have the dreadful feeling you have disappointed him deeply.[/p] [p]He says, in a tired old-man voice, “Come, gather round me and do exactly as I say.”[/p] [p]He turns and taps the wall with his staff. Snick! The wall opens, and cool darkness surrounds you. You realize night has fallen.[/p] [p]You walk onto a narrow ledge battered by fierce winds. The ruins of the kingdom lie on your left. To your right, there is a dizzying fall into a valley thousands of feet below.[/p] [p]Pentegarn looks like a swirling gray cloud as the wind whips his cloak and hair against his frail body.[/p] [p]“Is it too late to go home?” asks Fox.[/p] [p]“Put all thoughts of home from your minds,” says Pentegarn, pointing his staff up the mountain.“That is our destination.”[/p]

[p]In the distance, you see a tall, narrow tower standing against the stormy night sky. A narrow spine of rock connects it to the mountain. One dim light burns at the tower’s base.[/p] [p]“We have only one way of getting to the tower safely,” says Pentegarn. “Although it has its risks, too.”[/p]

[p]Fortunately, you have time to do your chores before your mother returns.[/p] [p]Even though the south wind holds, you do not have any desire to run off to the woods. Over the next few days, you’re so good your mother thinks you’re sick. But you’re not sick, you’re just scared.[/p] [p]You often wonder how the adventurers are doing, but since you would need to go to the Pillars of Pentegarn to find out, the question remains unanswered.[/p] [p]Would your help have made any difference?[/p] [p]Unfortunately, you’ll never know.[/p] [p class="end"]THE END[/p] [p class="inlineImage" data-img="9"][/p]

[p]The goblins are approaching too fast for you to escape.[/p] [p]“Hurry,” says Pentegarn, “follow me!”[/p] [p]Pentegarn leads you to a hill overlooking the path and tells you his plan. The ugly jabbering creatures arrive all too soon. They rush along the narrow path below the hill.[/p] [p]On Pentegarn’s signal, you all rise and throw slabs of broken rock down upon the unsuspecting goblins. Screams of terror and rage burst forth from the foul monsters. They scramble to escape, but the hill is too steep. You continue to hurl the rubble down upon their heads, burying them all within minutes.[/p] [p]“We have won this encounter,” Pentegarn gasps after the last rock is thrown, “But it appears our passage will not pass unnoticed. Quickly, into the cavern!”[/p] [p]You follow Pentegarn into the cavern, and once again you are traveling on a high ledge, this time inside the mountain. Vast numbers of goblins make machines of war on the cavern floor far below.[/p]

[p]Never have you seen so many goblins![/p] [p]All of you stop for a moment, stunned by the terrible sight. As you watch, the goblins at the far end of the cavern begin to mill about in fear. Finally, they abandon order and run in all directions.[/p] [p]A familiar dry clacking noise reaches your ears, and you see the reason for the goblins’ panic. A skeleton patrol appears, marching in dreadful deadly precision. It makes you feel better to see the goblins scattering in fear, and you take advantage of their confusion to hurry along the ledge unnoticed.[/p] [p]When you reach the end of the ledge, Pentegarn says, “We have two choices now. We can sneak through the dungeon, trying to avoid detection, or we can approach the tower directly. Which do you prefer?”[/p]
p.next: If you want to go to the tower
If you want to sneak through the dungeon

p.text: [p]“Gather about me closely,” Pentegarn says. “Everyone hold on to my cloak. Jaimie, tuck Fox inside your shirt. Owl, hold on!”[/p] [p]Pentegarn closes his eyes and whispers some magic words.[/p] [p]You look down at your legs, and discover you no longer stand on the ledge. You are floating in mid-air![/p] [p]“Great Zorn!” exclaims Baltek.[/p] [p]Pentegarn’s eyes remain closed, and he continues to murmur words you do not understand. His staff points at the top of the tower, which is growing ever close. You close your eyes, not daring to look down.[/p] [p]After what seems like an eternity of flying, you gently bump onto the top of the tower. As soon as your feet touch the roof of the tower, Pentegarn collapses. All of the strength seems to have left his body.[/p] [p]You rush to his side, gasping, “Pentegarn, are you all right? Don’t die!”[/p] [p]His eyes flicker open and rest on your face. “Would you care so much, Jaimie?” He pauses. “Don’t worry, if I rest for a moment I’ll be all right. But I’m glad you care, and perhaps this is the time to tell you something very important.[/p]

[p]“Have you never wondered why you have abilities others do not – such as speaking with animals? Did you not feel a kinship the first time we met?”[/p] [p]You think back and realize all Pentegarn says is true. You nod your head.[/p] [p]Pentegarn continues, “The blood of kings and queens runs in your veins, for I am your great grandfather! I have little to offer you other than knowledge of your heritage, but if we live through this, I would have you become my apprentice. When we recover the staff, you will have much to learn, for one day it will be yours!”[/p] [p]Your eyes water, and you are near tears when Lydia suddenly screams, “Baltek! Where’s Baltek?”[/p] [p]Leaping to your feet, you look about wildly. Baltek is gone! The only thing on the roof, other than yourselves, is a trap door, now lying open. You can see a ladder leading down the opening.[/p] [p]The elf rushes over to the ladder. “He’s left us! He’s gone off on his own! He’ll take all the treasure!” She climbs over the edge of the hole and starts down the ladder.[/p] [p]“No! No, Lydia,” you scream, tugging on her arm. “Come back! We have to discuss this.”[/p]

[p]“What is there to discuss? That accursed son of Zorn has gone off on his own, and he’ll get everything before we do!”[/p] [p]“Lydia, calm down! He’s our fighter. Maybe he’s only gone ahead to check things out!”[/p] [p]“I’m the thief!” flashes Lydia. “If anyone checks things out, it should be me – not that big, clumsy, muscle-bound clod!”[/p] [p]“Lydia, even if he did find treasure, it’s not likely he could – or would – just walk out the front door with it. He’ll be back; we mustn’t run off in different directions. Our only chance to win is to strike together.” “Tell that to muscle-brain!” mutters the elf, but she comes back up the ladder and sits with a flump at Pentegarn’s feet.[/p] [p]“I still think we should go after him,” snarls Lydia. “If he’s not robbing us, he’ll need our help.”[/p]
p.next: If you think you should go after Baltek
If you think you should wait for Baltek to return

p.text: [p]Fox’s cries echo from rock to rock.[/p] [p]“That stupid animal will awaken every monster in the kingdom,” Pentegarn mutters in great exasperation. “We’ll have to rescue the blasted beast whether we want to or not. Curses!”[/p] [p]He turns and stomps off toward the shrieks.[/p] [p]As you start down the mountain, Owl says, “I’ve always warned Fox he doesn’t deliberate long enough before he takes action. Haste makes waste, you know.”[/p] [p]Fox’s cries grow ever louder as you scramble down the broken piles of stone. Finally, you see two goblins poking at a dark hole with long pikes and a sword. The tip of Fox’s tail lies on a rock outside the hole. You hear Fox yelping pitifully inside the hole. Each time he yelps, the goblins laugh loudly and thrust a sword or pike into the hole.[/p] [p]Without saying a word, Baltek and Lydia sneak up behind the goblins and dispatch them with two swift blows. Pentegarn drops down to his hands and knees, peering into the hole. “Stop your infernal screeching,” he orders Fox. “Come out here now!”[/p] [p]A very dejected Fox creeps sadly out of the hole. Whimpering with pain, he crawls into your arms. He curls his squared-off tail under his belly and presses his muzzle under your arm.[/p]

[p]“I hope you learned something, Fox!” Pentegarn says harshly. “We must stick together. Together we stand a fair chance, but alone we are doomed.[/p] [p]“Even more importantly, we must travel silently,” he adds. “You were making enough noise to awaken the dead!”[/p] [p]As Pentegarn speaks, you hear a strange clacking coming up the slope. You have never heard such a noise before. It sounds like dead trees bumping against each other in a winter wind.[/p] [p]“Oh no!” whispers Lydia. “We have awakened the dead!”[/p] [p]An army of skeletons marches into view out of the darkness. Each carries a sword or polearm![/p] [p]“A skeleton patrol!” whispers Pentegarn. “Some of those were my men, good and true, but now they answer the bidding of the Evil One. We must defeat them, or all is lost!”[/p] [p]“Jaimie, pick up a sword!” says Baltek.[/p] [p]You are not used to battle, but it appears you must fight or die. You take a sword from one of the fallen goblins.[/p] [p]The skeletons advance mechanically and soon reach you. Holding their swords stiffly in front of their bony bodies, they hack and slash continuously. You smash the first skeleton to pieces with one good blow as it comes into striking range. Even though you destroy one skeleton after another, they continue to press forward, counting on their vast numbers to win the battle.[/p] [p class="inlineImage" data-img="16"][/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="18"][/p] [p]Finally, you and Baltek shatter the last two skeletons and the advance stops.[/p] [p]“That wasn’t so bad!” you say.[/p] [p]“You think not, Jaimie?” asks Pentegarn, touching a skeleton with his foot. “Had they landed a killing blow, you would have become a skeleton in the Evil One’s service.”[/p] [p]You are overcome by shaking. How could you have forgotten?[/p] [p]“We shall have to be more than cautious,” Pentegarn says. “For death at the hands of a skeleton means more than defeat, it means everlasting service to the Evil One.”[/p] [p]With that, Pentegarn leads the way back up the mountain and onto the path. You are passing the ruins of an ancient building and nearing a large hole in the ground when you hear a loud outcry from behind you. Looking back, you see a patrol of goblins standing on a wall.[/p] [p]They pour down the wall and onto the path, screaming loudly.[/p] [p]You may:[/p]
p.next: Stay and fight
Run into the opening and try to lose them

p.text: [p]“I don’t think we can defeat all the skeletons Baltek says are down there. Let’s go up and try another way,” you say.[/p] [p]Lydia quickly climbs the ladder into the room above. Pentegarn follows her slowly, but you and Baltek are right behind urging him on. As you start up the ladder, the first of the skeletons enters the room.[/p] [p]“Go ahead, kid!” Baltek says, “I’ll hold them off.”[/p] [p]Baltek jumps into the middle of the skeletons, swinging his sword mightily.[/p] [p]An evil laugh booms throughout the tower, and Lydia screams from above you. Pentegarn starts back down the ladder.[/p] [p]“Goblins, dozens of them!” screams Lydia.[/p] [p]Skeletons are pouring into the room below, and both Pentegarn and Lydia are trying to climb down the ladder. You are trapped![/p] [p]Baltek is overcome by skeletons, but you can see he has taken over a dozen of the gruesome monsters with him. Looking up, you see goblins poking Lydia and Pentegarn with spears. Knowing you are doomed whether you stay on the ladder or not, you draw your sword and jump into the room of skeletons. You are determined to take at least as many of the foul monsters with you as Baltek did.[/p] [p class="end"]THE END[/p]

[p]“With all due respect, sir,” you say nervously, “ do we have to go any of those ways? I’m not very good at fighting and bashing my way through things. And, to be honest, this sneaking business doesn’t sound very pleasant either.”[/p] [p]The thief flushes deep red and reaches for her dagger. Pentegarn puts out his hand and gently stops her action.[/p] [p]“Nor do I like the idea of going into a dungeon,” you continue cautiously. “If something went wrong, we’d be trapped under the earth.” A shiver of fear runs down your spine. “Isn’t there some other way we could go?”[/p] [p]“Yes,” Pentegarn says hesitantly, “I suppose there is. We could go over and through the ruins of my castle. It is a fairly direct route. Yes, yes, we could do that.”[/p] [p]“If you please sir, that’s what I’d like to do.”[/p] [p]“A good choice, child. I should have thought of it myself. We’d best get started.”[/p] [p]Holding the staff with both hands, Pentegarn taps the ceiling once, twice, three times. A section of it rum bles back to reveal the night sky.[/p]

[p]“Away you go” says the fighter, boosting you through the opening. Soon, all of you stand outside the small hole. Pentegarn taps the ground gently and the missing sections fall neatly into place.[/p] [p]“Now,” says the wizard, “we have two choices. We can go into the Hall of Kings, or we can go through a secret tunnel into the Hall of Past Glories. Which shall it be?”[/p]
p.next: If you choose the Hall of Kings
If you choose to go through the secret tunnel into the Hall of Past Glories

p.text: [p]“I don’t think we’d better try the magic stuff,” Baltek says, “I wouldn’t eat a cake that had been in the pantry for two hundred years. I don’t think we’d be smart to mess with two hundred year old magic ingredients, either. We might get killed.”[/p] [p]“All right Baltek, you’ve made your point,” sighs Lydia. “Where do we go now?” “Through that door,” gestures the wizard. “It leads into the throne room. If the Evil One is here, that’s where we’ll find him.”[/p] [p]“What are we standing here for?” asks Baltek. “Let’s get on with it.”[/p] [p]Baltek strides to the massive door and yanks on the handle. It does not open.[/p] [p]“Here, let me try,” hisses Lydia. She works with the lock, but again nothing happens.[/p] [p]“It must be rusted shut,” she snaps, stepping back and folding her arms.[/p] [p]Pentegarn steps up to the door and says, “Now stand aside, I have a door to unlock.” With a wave of his hand, the lock clicks and the door opens a crack.[/p]

[p]Choking back your fear, you duck under the pillars and enter the darkness. Glancing back, you see the goblins hard on your heels.[/p] [p]With the goblin cries echoing in the passage, you run as fast as you can, even though you have trouble seeing. Luckily, your long legs outdistance the goblins as you race down the corridor, but your breath soon rasps in your throat. You cannot last much longer without rest.[/p] [p]As you round the corner, a crumbling staircase rises upward into the darkness. The passage splits at the bottom and leads both left and right. You lean against the staircase and try to catch your breath, pressing your fingers against the stone wall. You feel ancient stone carvings under your hands. The cries of the goblins draw closer[/p] [p]“Well, featherhead,” pants Fox, “got any hot ideas now?”[/p] [p]“It is my astute opinion that – AWWWKH”[/p] [p]The carving moves under your fingers and a section of the staircase opens without warning. You fall backward into darkness![/p] [p]“Hey,” Fox cries. “Wait for me!” He slips through the opening.[/p] [p]The wall quickly snicks shut and darkness closes around you. The dark is thicker and more complete than any you have ever known.[/p]

[p]Goblin feet pound up the stairway you are hiding under, and then there is a long silence.[/p] [p]Finally, Fox says, “I don’t know how to tell you this, but we’re not alone.”[/p] [p]“That is correct!” a deep voice says.[/p] [p]“Who’s there?” you demand, trying to sound brave. In answer, a burst of light fills the room. A wrinkled old man leans on a staff in front of you.[/p] [p]He seems more ancient and frail than anyone you have ever seen. A bright, torchlike light leaps from his staff.[/p] [p]A young fighter stands on the old man’s right, pointing his sword at you. His battle-scarred armor and bulging muscles tell you this is not someone to anger.[/p] [p]A beautiful elven maiden stands on the left. Bright red hair hangs to her waist. She wears carefully tailored leather armor. Her hand rests on a polished dagger handle, and she watches you intently with bright green eyes.[/p] [p]“Oh boy,” mutters Fox. “We’re in for it now.”[/p] [p]“Patience, Fox,” Owl says, “I have found hasty judgment leads to disaster.”[/p] [p]“I can’t think of anything more disastrous than dying,” he answers.[/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="27"][/p] [p]“Fox! Owl!” cries the old man in a papery, dry voice. “Do not waste your strength arguing with each other. Neither the fighter Baltek nor the elven thief Lydia will harm you.”[/p] [p]You stare in amazement as Fox and Owl stop arguing and walk across the floor toward the old man. They understood the old man and he understood them! “Surprised, child?” he asks. “Don’t be. Like you, I can speak with animals, and so can those with me.[/p] [p]He pauses, and you back away from him.[/p] [p]“Do not worry, Jaimie,” he continues, “I am not one to fear. Come. Sit beside me. I shall tell you and your friends everything you need to know.”[/p] [p]He holds out his hand. His eyes are kindly and intelligent and hold all the strength his body lacks. Without a word, you cross the small space between you and clasp the waiting hand.[/p] [p]Fixing his gentle yet powerful gaze on you, he begins. “Although it seems unlikely, this was once a beautiful place. There were no goblins, no monsters, no death, no destruction. The fields were fertile. The people were prosperous and happy and blessed my name, the name of King Pentegarn.[/p]

[p]“Although I was a wise and good king, I did not do it alone. I was aided by a great magical staff. It was given to me by my father, who had received it from his father before him, who had received it from his father before him. It contains the magic and knowledge of all of those lifetimes.[/p] [p]“Unfortunately, in the hands of evil it can be used with terrible results, as you see by this foul ruin.[/p] [p]“One night, as I slept, a black fog covered the kingdom. By the time we discovered this was a magical fog, it was too late. It had cloaked the coming of the Evil One. In the darkness of the magic fog, the Evil Master crept into my castle and stole my magic staff.[/p] [p]“When the sun rose, it could not pierce the black gloom. Most of my people fled in fear, and those who stayed to fight were killed by the black cloud. I fought desperately, but without my staff I was all but helpless.[/p] [p]“At last, I neared total exhaustion. All about me was ruin, and I was forced to leave my own kingdom. Though I was too weak to battle my unseen foe any longer, I vowed I would return.[/p] [p]“Year after year I have returned, seeking to defeat the Evil One and regain what is rightfully mine. This is my last attempt. The staff holds much of my strength and without it I grow ever weaker.[/p] [p class="inlineImage" data-img="28"][/p]

[p]“Yet if I die, there will be nothing to stop the enemy.” He pauses, then adds, “It must be stopped now, and you must help me!” The old man stares intensely at each of you. As his eyes lock upon yours, you feel deeply drawn to him. His mission becomes yours. You believe, as the old man does, that you can, that you must, succeed.[/p] [p]Pentegarn continues, “The Master, as it calls itself, usually remains in the central tower. Between us and the tower are many halls, caverns, and passageways. They will be guarded by bands of goblins and skeletons, all of whom serve the Evil One.[/p] [p]“Although there are few ways to defeat the Evil One, I have a plan. A Cube of Mystic Forces and a Ring of Spell Turning lie hidden in the depths of the dungeon beneath the castle. I do not believe the Master possesses them. If we can get them, we stand an excellent chance of success.” “I don’t agree with you,” says the elf. “Wouldn’t it be better to sneak straight through? We can avoid discovery as well as fighting, and perhaps pick up some treasure along the way.”[/p] [p]“Me, I’m more in favor of a direct approach,” says the fighter. “I suggest we move slowly, from one area to the next, fighting when necessary.”[/p]

[p]The old man fastens his gaze upon you.[/p] [p]“And you, little one?” he asks in a soft voice. “What do you think? Which of the ways would you choose?”[/p] [p]“M-m-me?” you stammer. “I’m just a kid. I don’t know anything.”[/p] [p]“Age has little to do with intelligence,” replies the old man. “Do not take yourself so lightly. You and your friends have much to offer. What is your choice?”[/p]
p.next: You may choose the old man’s course of action
You may choose the elf s way
You may choose the fighter’s way

dontHave.next: Or you may choose your own way

p.text: [p]“Let’s go through the tunnel,” says Lydia, “I feel better underground. There are too many eyes above ground.”[/p] [p]“Sounds good to me,” says Baltek. “I like narrow areas myself; they’re much easier to defend.”[/p] [p]Fox agrees and follows behind the thief.[/p] [p]“Majority rules,” says the elf firmly. “We take the tunnel.”[/p] [p]“All right, then,” says the wizard. “Follow me.”[/p] [p]A cold wind whistles through the dark air as you pick your way over fallen columns, large blocks of stone, and shattered statues of ancient men. The black mouth of a tunnel looms ahead, and dread washes over you.[/p] [p]Hiding your fears, you follow the elf maiden into the darkness. Silence, thick and uncomfortable, swallows you. You feel as though evil, dark-loving creatures watch your every action. Your party bunches together around the dim light cast by Pentegarn’s staff.[/p] [p]You have gone only a few yards when Owl says, “My superior eyesight tells me there is an obstruction directly ahead.”[/p] [p]Not to be outdone, Fox adds, “My superior sense of smell tells me goblins are hiding behind that obstruction.”[/p]

[p]All eyes look to Pentegarn for direction. “There is no point in fighting them there,” he says. “This path has been claimed by the Evil One. We will have to go on to the Hall of Kings, or return to the secret room under the stairs and choose another course of action.”[/p]
p.next: If you choose to go to the Hall of Kings
If you want to return to the secret room and take another path

p.text: [p]“Let’s stay here and smash them as they come out of the hole,” you say.[/p] [p]“Good idea!” Baltek says. “Why didn’t I think of that?”[/p] [p]As you speak, the first skeleton sticks its bony head out of the hole. Baltek quickly smashes it, and the skeleton falls back down. Like the mindless creatures they are, the skeletons continue to climb the ladder, and Baltek continues to smash them. A few manage to squeak past Baltek, but you and Lydia dispatch them quickly.[/p] [p]The skeletons keep coming, though you are certain you have slain at least fifty of the foul creatures. Finally, Baltek tires, and six of the creatures surge into the room. They attack Baltek immediately, and, though both you and Lydia swing your swords with all your might, you cannot save the mighty warrior.[/p] [p]When, you have reduced the skeletons to nothing more than a pile of bones, Baltek lies dead beside the hole.[/p] [p]Lydia lets out a great moan, but Pentegarn quiets her.[/p] [p]“We must leave here before Baltek falls into the Evil One’s service,” he says. “We will grieve for him after we have taken our revenge.”[/p]

[p]Lydia refuses to move. “We’re walking into a trap,” she says. “The Evil One is down there with more goblins and skeletons waiting for us.”[/p] [p]“I do not doubt you are correct,” Pentegarn says. “But I do not see anything to do but meet the enemy.”[/p] [p]“We should find another way into the chamber,” Lydia says. “Perhaps a secret door.”[/p] [p]“There were no secret doors when I owned this tower,” Pentegarn says.[/p] [p]“That was a long time ago,” snaps Lydia, “I wouldn’t be surprised to find the Evil One has many secret doors where you had few.”[/p] [p]“You may try if you wish, but I must meet the enemy now,” Pentegarn says.[/p] [p]With that, Pentegarn climbs down the ladder.[/p]
p.next: If you choose to follow Pentegarn into the enemy’s trap
But if you think it might be better to try to find another way into the chamber

p.text: [p]“I choose the tunnel!” says Lydia.[/p] [p]You quickly cross to her side and say, “I really don’t like being underground. Could we please choose the Hall of Kings? I know you’ll understand, because even though you’re as brave as Baltek, I’ll bet there’s something you don’t like.”[/p] [p]At first the thief glares at you, but her eyes finally warm. She smiles and says, “You’re right. I can’t stand bats. Just the thought of them makes my skin crawl. Let’s go to your Hall of Kings.”[/p] [p]You are soon threading your way between a line of jagged pillars. They rise high into the night sky.[/p] [p]“There used to be a roof connecting them,” sighs the wizard. “It was really quite grand.” Thick swirls of sand muffle your footsteps as you march toward the ruins of a large chamber. A set of double doors, nearly twenty feet tall, hang loosely on their hinges.[/p] [p]“No need to knock,” barks Fox. “Let’s hope no one’s home.”[/p]

[p]Slipping between the yawning doors, you find yourself standing in a wide corridor that stretches into total darkness.[/p] [p]“The hall of my ancestors,” Pentegarn whispers. “How grieved they would be to see their kingdom now.”[/p] [p]The rasp of steel on steel rings through the room suddenly. “Stand back,” cries the fighter. “We are surrounded!”[/p] [p]You peer into the darkness, and you can barely see dozens of man-like shapes in the black room.[/p] [p]“No, dear fellow,” Pentegarn says. “Put away your sword. There is no danger from this quarter. I will show you.”[/p] [p]Pentegarn lights the room with his staffs flickering light, and you see statues stretching as far along the hall as you can see.[/p] [p]“Let me introduce my ancestors,” says the old wizard proudly.[/p] [p]You approach the figures slowly and with a certain amount of dread. One by one, Pentegarn passes each figure and recites his or her name, telling of battles long past.[/p]

[p]The first stone king holds a staff much like the one Pentegarn holds; a young and plain sapling with some carvings at its top. As you pass each king’s statue, the staff grows and changes until it is a complex blend of beauty and power.[/p] [p]As you stand in front of the last statue, admiring the beauty and power of the staff, Pentegarn says quietly, “My father.”[/p] [p]You notice, with astonishment, that Pentegarn’s father wears an amulet that looks exactly like the one your mother gave you. You raise your hand to your chest, where the amulet still hangs under your shirt. Could it be the amulet Pentegarn’s father wore?[/p] [p]As if reading your thoughts, Lydia asks Pentegarn, “What is that necklace?” “That, my dear, is the Amulet of Power, a most wonderful device. Unfortunately, it was lost when the kingdom fell and I have riot been able to recover it. If I had it, our job would be much easier.”[/p]

[p]As you are about to reveal the amulet to Pentegarn, a crazed howling fills the hall. You turn to see two large wolves running toward you. The beasts have glowing red eyes and ugly white teeth.[/p] [p]“Quickly,” cries Owl. “There’s not a moment to loose!”[/p] [p]Hearts racing wildly, all of you dash through the dusty darkness. The insane howling follows, lapping at your heels. You can see two doors ahead, one to the right and one to the left.[/p] [p]“Which way, old man?” Lydia shouts.[/p] [p]“A guardroom lies on the right and an antechamber to the left,” Pentegarn gasps in answer.[/p] [p]Lydia quickly presses her ear to both doors. “I hear scurry ing in the antechamber; nothing in the guardroom.”[/p]
p.next: If you decide to enter the antechamber
If you decide to enter the guardroom

p.text: [p]“I think we should follow Lydia’s suggestion,” you say.[/p] [p]“Good thinking, kid! I’ll show you some fancy slinking. Follow me!” exclaims Fox.[/p] [p]“It does seem, indeed, this course of action may yield favorable results, although it is not without its own inherent perils,” Owl says.[/p] [p]“You are a wise youngster,” says the elf. Her dark green eyes beam approval.[/p] [p]The old man looks at you quietly. “So be it,” he says in an old, soft voice. He gestures with his hands. Snick! The wall behind him opens into darkness.[/p] [p]“Come,” he says. “The die is cast, and it is time for us to be upon our way.”[/p] [p]All of you file past him and enter the darkness beyond.[/p] [p]As you leave, the wall slides shut behind you with a very final click![/p] [p]You now stand outside, a brisk chill wind whistling about you.[/p] [p]“Watch it, kid,” Fox yaps. “Your fingers are pretty nimble, but your feet aren’t so hot!”[/p] [p]You look around and see you are walking a very narrow trail bordering the ruins of the kingdom. The remains of ancient buildings lie on your left, lit here and there by flickering fires. On your right you see a sheer fall. The edge of the mountain drops away only a few inches from the path![/p] [p class="inlineImage" data-img="40"][/p]

[p]Pentegarn stops and clutches your elbow. “There it is!” he whispers, raising a bony finger and pointing up the trail.[/p] [p]You see a tall black tower rising high against the night sky. As you study the tower, a terrible howl grows in the wind and hangs in the air. Shivers of terror run down your spine.[/p] [p]“That is our goal,” the old man says. “Some of us may not survive our journey into it, but the mission is more important than our lives.”[/p] [p]“Great!” says Fox. “Listen, kid, I just remembered I’ve got to rush home. See you!”[/p] [p]With that, Fox darts away down the trail.[/p] [p]Fox has not been gone more than three seconds before terrible screams tear the quiet of the night. “YIIII! YOWWWWL!”[/p] [p]“Fox! Fox!” you cry. Even louder screams answer your cries.[/p] [p]You have two choices. You may:[/p]
p.next: Rush down the trail into the dark and attempt to rescue your friend, no matter what danger faces you
Consider the good of the entire party, rather than feelings for Fox

p.text: [p]“I say let’s continue,” you urge, “I don’t want to go back.”[/p] [p]You sneak through the doorway into the throne room.[/p] [p]At first you see nothing, then out of the darkness a bright red light appears. It soon turns clear white and arcs toward you.[/p] [p]As your eyes adjust to the light, you see a darkly robed figure sitting on a great throne. It clutches a great, glowing staff. You gasp with shock, for the same emblem you saw on the statue of Pentegarn’s father is embedded on the head of the staff. It is the same emblem you bear on your amulet![/p] [p]“Pentegarn,” you say, “look!” You pull the emblem from under your shirt. But the old man has eyes only for his enemy. Pentegarn points his staff to do battle.[/p] [p]“Begone!” he booms. “Begone from my kingdom, and take your evil with you.”[/p] [p]A flash of light shoots out of Pentegarn’s small staff, but it dies when it reaches the Evil One.[/p] [p]Wicked laughter bursts from the figure. “I should have left my helpers behind. I won’t need them to defeat you.”[/p] [p]The Evil One waves his hand, and a dim light glows throughout the room. Only now are you aware of various creaks, clacks, squeaks, and growls of the armed skeletons, huge wolves, and horde of bats that surround the Evil One.[/p]

[p]“You have plagued me too long, old man,” the Evil One hisses. It points its staff and a thin beam of red light shoots at Pentegarn. The beam hits Pentegarn’s staff and travels its length, shattering and burning the wood. After traveling through the staff, the beam strikes Pentegarn. The old man crumples to his knees, dropping his smoldering staff.[/p] [p]“Die!” screams the evil figure.[/p] [p]Pentegarn falls to the ground.[/p] [p]“No!” you cry. You run up the stairs toward the black figure, holding the amulet before you. A yellow beam shoots out of the amulet and locks onto the red beam coming from the Evil Master’s staff. The red beam drops from Pentegarn’s body immediately, and the great staff glows lemon yellow.[/p] [p]A shriek of pain erupts from the Black Master and a yellow glow bathes its body. It falls to the ground and starts growing smaller and smaller and smaller.[/p] [p]At last, whining and writhing, the thing on the steps disappears completely. At the same moment, the skeletons fall to the ground and shatter, no longer animated by their master’s powers.[/p] [p]The rest of the room erupts with the sounds of battle. The wolves and bats battle Baltek and Lydia, who became visible with their first attack.[/p]

[p]Suddenly, you realize you hold the Staff of Kings. It glows with a pale amber light that fills the large chamber. You point the staff in the direction of the fight, and a great light blinds you. When you can see again, the wolves and bats have fled, and Baltek, Lydia, and Pentegarn kneel at your feet.[/p] [p]“Please sir, don’t do that,” you say. “Take your staff back.”[/p] [p]Pentegarn rises to his feet. Tears run down his cheeks, but he smiles with joy.[/p] [p]“It’s not my staff, dear child. It is yours. The blood of kings and queens flows in your veins. If I had any doubts, they were dispelled by the amulet. No one can wear the amulet unless they are of our blood. You, Jaimie, are my great grandchild.[/p] [p]“You will raise the city to its former glory. Fear will be cleansed from the land, and you will rule wisely and well.”[/p] [p]“Didn’t you forget the part about riches and wealth beyond measure?” asks Lydia, sheathing her sword.[/p] [p]“You shall have them,” you say, “if they are mine to give.”[/p] [p]“Indeed they are, Jaimie,” Pentegarn says, “indeed they are. Perhaps Baltek will even volunteer to lead your palace guard!”[/p] [p]“If you will have me,” Baltek says, bowing, “I would consider it a privilege.”[/p] [p class="end"]THE END[/p]

[p]You back away from the dragon-skeleton, hoping Pentegarn can escape on his own. But, unfortunately, the skeleton opens its toothy mouth and lowers its huge head. Pentegarn tries to protect himself, but he falls to the ground as he backs away.[/p] [p]The monster grabs Pentegarn in its mouth. Realizing that Pentegarn is finished if you do nothing, you charge the monster, swinging your sword wildly. The skeleton lowers one great claw and grasps you. Your arms are completely trapped, and you cannot even move your toes.[/p] [p]Carrying you in its claw and Pentegarn in its mouth, the great dragon turns and moves back into the dark cavern. Looking back at your only hope, Lydia and Baltek, you see the creature’s huge tail swish and send them flying across the room.[/p] [p]It looks like this is...[/p] [p class="end"]THE END[/p]

[p]“I think we should try for the Cube of Mystic Forces,” you say. “We’ll need all the help we can get.”[/p] [p]Without further comment, Pentegarn strides off down a corridor, and you all follow. Surprisingly, you meet no enemies. Soon, you stand in the cavern with the pillar that covers the cube.[/p] [p]Impatient, Pentegarn strides over to the pillar and grabs its base.[/p] [p]“What are you waiting for? Help me, Baltek.”[/p] [p]Baltek quickly scrambles to Pentegarn’s side. The two men grunt and groan. Sweat pours from both their brows, and finally the pillar rises. Lydia quickly snakes her hand underneath the pillar.[/p] [p]“I’ve got it!” she says.[/p] [p]She pulls the cube from beneath the pillar. Without even looking at it, she lays it aside.[/p] [p]As soon as she lays the cube on the ground, several goblins appear in the corridor at the edge of the cavern. They do not even hesitate; they charge straight at you and your friends.[/p] [p]Not pausing to think, you draw your sword and leap in front of your friends, none of whom are prepared to fight.[/p]

[p]The charging goblins stop, frightened, as you brace yourself to fight. But their eyes quickly narrow, and they start to rush you.[/p] [p]“Leave little one!” a large goblin screams from the back, “Get cube! Master want cube.”[/p] [p]The goblins rush. Not knowing what else to do, you throw your body at the front row of goblins. As your body thuds into them, they fall to the ground.[/p] [p]Before you can say “snazzlefrass,” ten more goblins jump on the pile, not wanting to miss the fun of pinching and poking you.[/p] [p]“Get off Morg,” one says. “You hurt.”[/p] [p]The goblins curse and shout at each other, but the pile on top of you doesn’t get any lighter. Many goblin hands pinch and squeeze you.[/p] [p]“Juicy,” one says. “This one good to eat.”[/p] [p]You try to struggle, but there are too many bodies on top of you.[/p] [p]The goblins suddenly quit pinching.[/p] [p]“Run away!” they scream, and bodies begin to pile off you. “Run away! Help, help! Light hurt.”[/p] [p]Within seconds, you lie on the ground alone. You shield your eyes, for the room is filled with painfully bright light. Finally, you peek from under your elbow. The light is becoming fainter.[/p] [p]“Stand up, Jaimie,” Pentegarn says.[/p]

[p]You stand up and look at Pentegarn, or the man who should be Pentegarn. But instead of the stately gentleman who walked into the room, you see a man as tall as Baltek.[/p] [p]“Pentegarn?” you ask.[/p] [p]“Yes,” he laughs, “I am restored to my full strength, thanks to your brave deed. Had you not thrown yourself at the goblin horde, they would have stolen the cube and all would have been lost.”[/p] [p]You look about and see your friends are kneeling, their heads bowed. You do the same. Even Fox lays his head on his paws and is silent.[/p] [p]“Arise, my friends. We must move quickly. There is still much to be done.”[/p] [p]Turning, Pentegarn races off down the corridor, and you follow in his footsteps.[/p]

[p]“Gosh, I don’t know,” you say. “It’s your kingdom and your magic stuff. If you think we should go for the cube first, how can I argue with you?”[/p] [p]“That’s it kid,” Fox yaps. “Stick with the power.”[/p] [p]“This seems a most wise decision,” Owl adds.[/p] [p]“Let us begin,” says Pentegarn. He walks down a tunnel on the right.[/p] [p]“This was a wise choice, Jaimie,” says Pentegarn. “I must admit I was worried you would make the wrong decision.”[/p] [p]“What does my decision count?” you ask. “I’m just a kid who happened to come along.”[/p] [p]“Nothing just happens, Jaimie. Nothing is ever really an accident. There is a grand destiny to our world, and your arrival was no chance happening.”[/p] [p]You stare in wonder at the old man beside you. , .[/p] [p]“What do you mean?” you ask in a trembling voice. “Did you know I was coming?”[/p] [p]“Not really,” answers Pentegarn. “Or rather, I did not know you were coming at this precise moment. But I did know it would happen. It was destined to happen.”[/p] [p]You walk through a long, narrow tunnel lit by streaks of color.[/p]

[p]“Pretty, isn’t it?” asks Pentegarn. “You mix six liters of Oil of Rainbows with one liter of Ointment of Fireflies.”[/p] [p]Soon, you walk into a cavern so high you can barely see the ceiling.[/p] [p]“Baltek,” Pentegarn says, “I think we may need your services. The cornerstone lies in this cavern.”[/p] [p]The walls of the huge cavern twinkle and glitter with brilliant streaks of color. In the center of the room an enormous, shiny block of stone sits. An equally large, shiny pillar rests atop the block. It rises high into the cavern.[/p] [p]“This is the Cornerstone of the Kingdom,” says Pentegarn. “The Cube of Mystic Forces lies beneath it. We must not fail in our attempts to retrieve the cube, for once the pillar is moved, the Evil One will know we are here.”[/p] [p]The fighter flexes his biceps and moves toward the cornerstone. He bends down and grasps the immense block. But before he can attempt to move the pillar, you hear a strange noise, as if someone were shaking a bunch of sticks together in a bag.[/p] [p]“Kid, I don’t like the sound of this,” says Fox. “How about checking out now?”[/p] [p]“Hush, Fox,” you say. You strain to see what makes the strange noise.[/p]

[p]The biggest skeleton you have ever seen stalks out of the gloom at the far edge of the vast cavern. It’s a dragon skeleton! It must measure forty feet from the end of its toothy mouth to its last tiny tailbone![/p] [p]It clacks toward you slowly.[/p] [p]Clutching your small sword, you leap in front of Pentegarn. Your knees are shaking, but the old man must be protected from the giant monster.[/p] [p]The fearful skeleton stops and stares at you. It has no eyes, but you feel the force of its sightless gaze as the head lowers.[/p] [p]Its sharp teeth glint in the rainbow light. Your knees shake harder.[/p] [p]Should you fight such a ferocious monster? It’s awfully large, and the chance that you can defeat it is very small indeed. If you fight, you will probably be devoured by the skeleton.[/p] [p]But you are the only thing that stands between the monster and Pentegarn. If you flee, it will certainly devour Pentegarn.[/p]
p.next: If you decide the monster is too terrible, and that you stand no chance of defeating it
If you decide you must stand and defend Pentegarn at any cost, even if it means battling such a terrifying monster

p.text: [p]“I think we should follow Lydia’s suggestion,” you say.[/p] [p]“So be it,” says Pentegarn. “Follow me.”[/p] [p]He leads you into a dark corridor with no exit. He raises his hands high above his head, points his fingers at the wall, and mutters some magic words.[/p] [p]Snick! The wall in front of him opens into the night. You walk outside and stand on a ledge high on the mountain. Ahead of you, a tall black tower rises high against the night sky.[/p] [p]“That tower is our goal,” Pentegarn says. “Some of us may not survive our journey into it, but our mission is more important than our lives.”[/p] [p]“Great!” says Fox. “I just remembered I have an appointment with the game warden.”[/p] [p]With that, Fox darts away down the ledge. It happens so quickly you do not have time to stop him.[/p] [p]The night is torn by terrible screams almost immediately. “YIIIII! YOWWWWL' YIIII!!”[/p] [p]You have two choices. You may:[/p]
p.next: Rush down the rubble into the dark and attempt to rescue your friend, no matter what the danger
Consider the good of the entire party and follow Pentegarn up the ledge

p.text: [p]“With that black fog, I don’t think we stand a chance,” you say. “I think we had better try to lure them in here.”[/p] [p]“My thoughts exactly,” Lydia says. “Here’s my plan.”[/p] [p]You listen to her plan, and put it into action quickly. Lydia jumps out of the hole leading into the tiny tunnel and screams, “What’s the matter, tiny tots? Afraid to fight?” She climbs back into the small tunnel immediately.[/p] [p]Just as you had hoped, several goblins follow her. You and Baltek quickly dispatch them. After a short time, several more goblins enter the hole, and they, too, meet their doom.[/p] [p]But no more come. Finally, a goblin calls, “Morg, come out. Don’t play games with Grog.”[/p] [p]When no answer comes, Grog calls, “Grog’s patrol go now. Leave heavy man for you to carry. Take his stuff to master. You learn to play games with Grog.”[/p] [p]Hearing these words, you and Baltek wait for the goblins to leave and step into the large room. Pentegarn lies on the ground, bound and gagged.[/p] [p]You quickly free Pentegarn. His cloak is in tatters, and he has been stripped of everything of value he carried.[/p] [p]“Did they get everything?” you ask.[/p]

[p]Pentegarn nods his head. “Everything except my staff. They left that over there,” he points toward the far side of the cavern. “They thought it was a worthless stick.” He looks broken-hearted, and once again his face has assumed the look of an old man.[/p] [p]“We shall have to try another way. The Evil One now expects us by this entrance. Give me my staff, please,” he says, rising.[/p] [p]You fetch the staff and give it to Pentegarn. As soon as you hand it to him, his face loses some of its age, and he appears to grow a little stronger.[/p] [p]“Is this staff magical, too?” you ask.[/p] [p]Pentegarn nods. “Yes, but it is not as powerful as the Staff of Kings. Building a magic staff takes years, Jaimie, and requires the wisdom and learning of many wise men. This staff,” he says, holding the small sapling out for you to see, “is much like you. It is just beginning its life, and it has much to learn. It can accomplish simple tasks, but we must take care not to demand too much of it. Now come, it is time for us to continue.”[/p] [p]He walks back to the stairs, with you and the rest of your party following. After a long climb, you stand outside looking at a black tower in the distance.[/p] [p]“That is our destination,” Pentegarn says.[/p]

[p]“Quick!” says Pentegarn. “Run for that hole!”[/p] [p]You run as fast as you can, Pentegarn lagging behind.[/p] [p]You reach the hole ahead of the goblins, but as you plunge through, a black fog rises in the large cavern behind you. Lydia tumbles through next.[/p] [p]She screams, “Bats! I hate bats!” You help her beat a dozen ugly bats away.[/p] [p]Finally, Baltek jumps through the hole.[/p] [p]“Pentegarn?” you ask.[/p] [p]Baltek shakes his head.[/p] [p]“We’ll have to rescue him,” you say quickly.[/p] [p]“I’m for it, let’s go get him!” Baltek urges.[/p] [p]“Not so fast,” Lydia says, “I think we’d better use our brains, not our brawn.”[/p]
p.next: If you want to do as Lydia suggests
If you don’t believe you have time toset up the trap, and want to go after Pentegarn immediately

p.text: [p]As you enter the doorway, you hear Fox screaming behind you. “Hey, wait for me! I’m coming too.” He jumps in behind you, panting. You are astonished, but happy to see him.[/p] [p]Fox clears his throat with embarrassment, and, avoiding your eyes, says, “Hi guys! Bet you thought I ran away because I was scared, but I was really saving your bacon. My keen sense of smell picked up the scent of goblins, and I tricked them into chasing me instead of you, then lost them in the brambles. Please don’t thank me... just remember how lucky you are to have me along.”[/p] [p]Pentegarn looks at Fox slyly, but says, “Yes, we are certainly lucky to have you along. Come along, now. We have very little time. ”[/p]

[p]You follow Pentegarn through the confusing tunnels. After twenty minutes of endless wandering, Pentegarn stops. You are in a dark corridor ending in a bare dirt wall. There is a wooden trap door a few feet above your head.[/p] [p]“Where are we?” you whisper.[/p] [p]“At the foot of the tower,” Pentegarn replies. “It is time to face our destiny.”[/p] [p]No sooner has he uttered the words than the trap door flies open. All is dark beyond. Pentegarn grasps the edge of the doorway and pulls himself into the darkness with one swift movement.[/p] [p]You cannot let Pentegarn go alone. But, even though you leap, you cannot reach the opening.[/p] [p]“Here, Jaimie. Your heart is larger than you are,” says Baltek.[/p] [p]Placing two large hands about your waist, he lifts you into the gloom above. Then he boosts Lydia and Fox up, following right behind them.[/p] [p]You are surrounded by silence, and you cannot see anything. “Maybe no one’s here,” you say hopefully.[/p] [p]“No!” hisses a deep, whispering voice. A brilliant, silvery light floods the room. The light springs from a staff of great age.[/p] [p]“Who’s there?” cries Pentegarn. “Who dares hold the Staff of Kings – the staff of Pentegarn?”[/p] [p class="inlineImage" data-img="58"][/p]

[p]A low laugh fills the room. “Don’t you know me, Pentegarn? We’ve met often enough.”[/p] [p]The light dims until it only glows softly. You now see dozens of skeletons and goblins, all armed and grinning, crowded against the far wall. The staff stands in the center of the room, glowing softly. A thick black cloud billows about its base.[/p] [p]As you watch, the cloud pulses and throbs as though alive. Then it mushrooms to enormous size, filling the room. Before your astonished eyes, the cloud turns into a large number of shrilling, chittering bats! They soar and wheel about your heads, the hot stink of their bodies filling your breath. Y ou strike wildly at the furry creatures, but they deftly avoid your blows.[/p] [p]Lydia screechs in fear, swinging her fists madly at the bats circling her head. Finally, after what seems like an eternity of terror, the bats disappear and the swirling black fog replaces them. Gasping for breath, Lydia falls into Baltek’s arms and clutches him tightly.[/p]

[p]The black fog slithers and twists, growing larger and smaller. It snakes close enough to touch, then draws away. It spins like a small cyclone beside the staff and disappears. In its place stands a huge black wolf with fire-red eyes and long white fangs. The wolf whines and snarls, its belly close to the ground. Its back legs bunch beneath it, and it springs at you![/p] [p]You throw your arms up to protect yourself from its attack, but the wolf disappears in mid-leap and the black fog returns.[/p] [p]Once more it twists and swirls, changing its size and shape with every breath. It moves back to its original spot beside the staff. Slowly, the form of a bent black figure clad in a black draping cloak emerges. The cloak covers it from head to toe. Its face is completely hidden. All you can see is a bit of swirling black fog – more terrifying than any face could be. It keeps its hands tucked inside the folds of its sleeves.[/p] [p]“As you can see,” a hollow voice hisses from the depths of the hood, “I have many faces. I am darkness. I am fear. I am your worst nightmares.” It pauses, the fog inside its hood rolling slowly, then continues in a thundering voice, “I command you to bow to my power! Your quest is hopeless!”[/p] [p]“No,” shouts Pentegarn. “Not so long as I live!” He raises his young staff, a mere twig compared to the Staff of Kings, and points it at the black figure.[/p]

[p]A bright shaft of lightning blasts out of the end of the staff toward the enemy. But the figure raises its hand and points its staff at Pentegarn. Pentegarn’s bolt stops in mid-air, trembles, and then retraces its passage. As the bolt strikes, it travels the length of the staff and explodes. Pentegarn’s staff bursts apart and falls to the ground, shattered into a million smoking pieces.[/p] [p]“Do not try your petty tricks on me,” the voice sneers. “How dare you challenge me when I have this?” It raises the mighty staff.[/p] [p]“I dare because I am the rightful king,” Pentegarn shouts back. “And because I have this – and this!” So saying, Pentegarn opens his hand to reveal the pulsating Cube of Mystic Forces. At the same time, he raises his other hand and shows the ring. The tiny serpents twist and glide around his finger, hissing fiercely.[/p] [p]The Evil One hesitates, its smoky hands writhing around the staff slowly and thoughtfully. Finally, it speaks, “It has amused me to watch you live your life in hopelessness, but now you dare challenge me! None may live who do not bow to my power!”lt points the staff at Pentegarn. “You no longer amuse me. Die!”[/p] [p class="inlineImage" data-img="62"][/p]

[p]“I do not choose to die,” Pentegarn answers calmly. He steps forward and grabs the Staff of Kings.[/p] [p]“Back! Back!” cries the dark figure. “Do not try!”[/p] [p]The staff glows dazzling silver, then dims to eerie red. It flashes silver once again, and begins to throb. The foes – one slight and frail, the other large and black – sway to and fro in the flashing light.[/p] [p]Suddenly, a tremendous boom echoes off the walls, and thick gray smoke fills the room. You begin coughing so hard you can barely stand. Even the goblins choke and wheeze.[/p] [p]When the smoke clears, you rub your burning eyes and strain to see the victor. You see the shattered remains of the skeletons, the bewildered goblins trying to find their master, and finally you see Pentegarn standing before you! The only sign the Evil One ever existed is a scorch on the floor.[/p] [p]Pentegarn turns his ring and staff toward the goblins and says, “I, Pentegarn, son of kings and rightful heir to this kingdom, command you to leave. I give you until morn to clear yourself and all your kind from my kingdom. Take nothing with you, and harm no one as you leave. Upon pain of unending death, I command this!”[/p]

[p]The goblins trip and fall over each other in their haste to escape, literally dropping through the trap door.[/p] [p]Pentegarn turns his attention to you and your companions. But this is a new Pentegarn, so unlike the kind old man you grew to love. You find it difficult to meet his bold gaze.You quickly kneel, and your companions do the same.[/p] [p]“Come, Jaimie. Do not be afraid. I am still myself and so are you. We are still friends. Thanks to your loyalty and bravery, we have won. Now is a time for great rejoicing, great efforts, and new beginnings.[/p] [p]“Soon we will have a feast of celebration, and at that feast, we will celebrate more than the rebirth of a kingdom. We will celebrate the discovery of the heir to the staff and my kingdom!”[/p] [p]You look about in wonder.[/p] [p]“I suppose you mean me,” says Fox.[/p] [p]Pentegarn’s deep laughter fills the small room. “No, Fox. Modest and brilliant though you are, I am not speaking of you. I am speaking of one who is honest and true, loyal and brave...”[/p] [p]“Sure sounds like me!” mutters Fox.[/p] [p]“Whose veins carry the blood of kings and queens.”[/p] [p]There is silence as everyone looks about in wonder.[/p]

[p]“I am speaking of you, Jaimie. You are my great grandchild, the heir to the kingdom.”[/p] [p]“Me? I’m your great grandchild?” you ask. “I’m your apprentice and your heir? Are you sure?”[/p] [p]“Yes, child, I am very sure. If you will continue to place your trust in me, I will take you as my apprentice and teach you all I know. One day the staff, the ring, and the cube will all be yours, as will the kingdom. So you must learn to be wise and strong now.”[/p] [p]“If you’ve got so much to share,” says Lydia, her hands on her hips, “how about us?”[/p] [p]“Yes,” barks Fox, “I want my share.”[/p] [p]“Can we afford a Fox muzzle?” asks Owl.[/p] [p]Pentegarn laughs, a great booming laugh, and says, “Lydia, Baltek, Fox, Owl, Jaimie; you will all share, and treasure is the least I have to offer. Come, my friends, gather round! We have much to discuss.”[/p] [p class="end"]THE END[/p] [p class="inlineImage" data-img="66"][/p]

[p]You fling yourself at the staff, praying you can knock it down and give your friends time to fight. You swing your sword ahead of your charge, hoping it will stop the goblins and skeletons before they reach you.[/p] [p]Before you reach the staff, however, three goblins throw themselves on you. One falls on your sword, but the other two grab your legs.[/p] [p]Pentegarn uses the confusion caused by your action to surprise the Evil One and grab the staff. The two struggle over the staff mightily, pushing and shoving each other into walls, causing the entire tower to shake.[/p] [p]Lydia springs into action, easily slaying one of the goblins who holds your legs. You slay the other. The two of you press your backs together and start swinging your swords at the horde of monsters.[/p]

[p]As soon as his head disappears, the trap door slams shut.[/p] [p]You run to the door and start pulling on its handle, but it will not open. Lydia quickly searches the room for secret doors, but returns to your side almost immediately.[/p] [p]“I’m afraid he was right,” she says. “There are no secret doors in this tower.”[/p] [p]You both pull on the door with all your strength. It pops open, sending you flying.[/p] [p]In the room below, you see Pentegarn struggling with a bent black figure. Pentegarn holds one end of a mighty staff, and the black figure’s smoky hands hold the other end. They are surrounded by dozens of goblins and skeletons.[/p] [p]With your sword swinging, you jump into the middle of the horde of monsters. Lydia quickly follows.[/p]

[p]Baltek charges to the door of the antechamber and opens it. “If we spend any more time discussing the problem, we’ll soon be dead. Let’s have more action and[/p] [p]Ipqq[/p] [p]“That’s my kind of talk!” says Fox.[/p] [p]“Of course, one would expect you to approve of that sort of foolish sentiment,” Owl comments.[/p] [p]“Quit hooting, Owl, or I’ll tie your beak in a knot!” growls the fighter. “Hurry, help me barricade the door we came in!”[/p] [p]Aided by the glow of the wizard’s staff, all of you pile rocks and beams against the door.[/p] [p]Two heavy thuds crash against the door, and the air is filled with howls and growls. The door shakes continuously under the attack of clawed feet. But it holds and at last the monsters withdraw, whining in frustration.[/p] [p]Baltek lowers his sword and heaves a deep breath. “Now we can go on. I wouldn’t want them on our trail for long!”[/p]

[p]“We are in the entrance to the Grand Council Chambers,” Pentegarn says. “The door in front of us leads to the council chambers, and the door to our right leads to the guard rooms.”[/p] [p]“I still hear squeaking and rustling in the council chambers,” says Owl.[/p]
p.next: If you enter the council chambers
If you enter the guard room

p.text: [p]You sit in silence for a long time.[/p] [p]Finally, you hear noises at the foot of the ladder. Lydia draws her dagger and you pull out your sword. Pentegarn stumbles to his feet and leans heavily upon his staff. You hear heavy breathing, then a head and shoulders appear.[/p] [p]Lydia screeches, “It’s Baltek! That pig-dog, he better not have any treasure!”[/p] [p]Baltek pulls himself onto the tower roof. Blood oozes from a small cut on his forehead.[/p] [p]“Sorry to keep you waiting,” he says.[/p] [p]“Did you find any gold?” demands Lydia.[/p] [p]“I only made it to the second room,” he answers, “I climbed into a goblin ambush.” He draws his sword and runs his finger along its edge. “But I finished them off before you could say Baltek-the-Great!”[/p] [p]“Did you get all of them?” Fox asks.[/p] [p]“Well,” Baltek hesitates, “one did sneak away, but he was bashed up pretty good.”[/p] [p]“Great,” Lydia snaps, “now the Evil One knows we’re coming.”[/p]

[p]“He knew we were coming, anyway,” Pentegarn says. “Now he knows to fear us. Let us give him more to fear!”[/p] [p]WTith that, he leads the way down the ladder into the tower. You cross one empty room, and climb down another ladder into a room full of dead goblins. The scene is impressive, indeed. At least twenty dead goblins lie scattered throughout the chamber.[/p] [p]As you study the scene, the most terrifying laugh you have ever heard rolls through the opening leading into the other room. Baltek starts down the ladder first, but as soon as his head disappears, you hear a mighty scream of fear. Baltek’s head reappears immediately, followed by the rest of his body.[/p] [p]“There are more skeletons down there than in any graveyard!” he says.[/p] [p]“Let’s get out of here!” Lydia screeches.[/p]
[p]“But we’re so close,” Pentegarn sighs. “It seems a pity to leave now.”[/p] [p]“It’s better to leave and try another route than to wait for those fellows to get us,” Baltek says.[/p]
p.next: If you want to run back up the ladder and try to get off the tower before the skeletons catch you
But if you think you can make your stand here and defeat the skeletons

p.text: [p]You quickly turn and run back up the steps. “Let’s get out of here,” you call. “We’ll find another way.”[/p] [p]Your friends follow, but Baltek soon stops and grabs a great boulder. “Go on!” he calls, “I’m going to slow them down a little.”[/p] [p]You run up the steps, and Baltek follows two seconds behind, carrying the boulder. Twenty feet up, Baltek stops and turns around. You turn around, too.[/p] [p]He rolls the boulder down the stairs. The goblins stop in their tracks, frozen with fear. Those in the front rows scream “Run away! Run away!”[/p] [p]The goblins in the back rows, protected by the bodies of their companions in front, press forward. “Coward!” they scream, ignoring the cries of the goblins caught in the boulder’s path. “Come back! Fight!”[/p] [p]Despite the fact that the boulder killed many goblins, you have no desire to fight those who remain. They chase you up the stairway, though they are slowed considerably by the boulder and the other goblins lying in their path.[/p] [p]You run to the top of the stairs and out into the night. Ahead, you see a tower glinting in the moonlight.[/p]

[p]You decide the good of the party must come before the good of an individual. But Fox begins to shriek and whine even more loudly, and you turn to rush to your friend. The heavy hand of the fighter grasps you firmly by the shoulder.[/p] [p]“You cannot go, Jaimie. Fox was unwise, but he made his own decision. No one forced him to leave,” Pentegarn says. “You cannot endanger the party by attempting his rescue. We must leave him to his fate.”[/p] [p]Still struggling, you are hurried off down the trail. Fox’s cries fade away, but they have been engraved upon your heart in pain.[/p] [p]You continue down the narrow wall until it meets the mountain. Soon, you must edge along the trail, spreading your arms flat against the mountain to balance your movement. Progress becomes very difficult to make.[/p] [p]At long last, the ledge ends in a wide rock shelf. “The worst is over,” Pentegarn says. “We are about to enter the great cavern, and our path will be much easier.”[/p] [p]He turns and faces the blank mountain wall, which rises smooth and unbroken. Raising his arms, he begins to chant.[/p] [p]A doorway grinds open where seconds before there was only solid, unbroken rock. You can see two passages going into the mountain.[/p]

[p]“Come, friends, we have no time to lose. Fortunately this will be an easy route.”[/p] [p]You are eagerly heading for the doorway when a long low growl stops you short. Four huge dog-like forms slink toward you from inside the mountain. But these are not dogs; they’re wolves! Foam drips off their long, white fangs. Their faces are hideous, snarling masks of evil. Their eyes glow like embers in a firepit.[/p] [p]“If this is going to be easy,” hoots Owl, “I’d hate to see it get hard!”[/p] [p]The wolves slink closer, and one leaps at you with a deep, threatening growl.[/p] [p]You have nowhere to go. The sheer edge of the mountain lies behind you, and the trail is too narrow to flee upon![/p] [p]You are slowly backing toward the doorway when a wolf jumps on your back, knocking you to the ground. You roll over and look into the mouth of a vicious wolf. Its glowing red eyes drill into yours, and its hot breath beats upon your face. It leans forward for a deadly bite.[/p] [p]Then you hear a great flapping of wings. It’s Owl! He is trying to draw the wolfs attention from you by attacking the evil creature. You roll away and press yourself against the doorway. Owl locks his talons into the wolf s head, and the ugly creature snaps and snarls with pain and rage. It whips its head from side to side, trying to shake the determined bird.[/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="79"][/p] [p]Just as you fear the wolf will free itself from Owl, Baltek rushes up and kills the enraged creature with one blow from his mighty sword. Owl falls to the ground and lies battered but breathing on the ledge. The fighter, too, bleeds from many wounds.[/p] [p]“Thank you, Baltek!” you say, “Owl and I both owe you our lives.”[/p] [p]The fighter nods, but has no energy left to reply. You look about the ledge. All of the huge beasts have been slain, but at great expense. Lydia lies beneath a wolf, her dagger buried in the great beast’s heart.[/p] [p]Pentegarn is collapsed against the wall. A wolf lies dead at his feet, burned to a crisp. Fearing the old man is dead, you slowly approach his crumpled form.[/p] [p]All is not lost – he lives! As you lean over him, the old man whispers, “What injuries have we taken?”[/p] [p]“I’m all right, and so is Owl, but Baltek bleeds badly, and Lydia may be dead.” “Well, we must see what we can do,” he says tiredly. “Please hand me my staff.” You pick up his staff and give it to him, then drag the body of the huge wolf off Lydia. She is covered with blood and lies very still on the cold ground.[/p] [p]Leaning down, Pentegarn cries, “Quick! There is life; we are in time. Hold her up, Jaimie!”[/p]

[p]Pentegarn draws forth a vial of smoky fluid. It shifts within the clear glass as though it has a life of its own. He carefully pours the precious potion between the thief s lips, a drop at a time. For one breathless moment, nothing happens. Then, at last, Lydia opens her eyes. She has the look of faraway visions in them.[/p] [p]“Pentegarn,” she sighs, “I’m so glad you’re not a wolf!”[/p] [p]“So am I,” chuckles the old man. “So am I! Now rest for a moment, my dear. You’ll be all right soon. I must see to Baltek.”[/p] [p]Though the fighter’s wounds are bloody, they are less serious and Pentegarn quickly tends to him. At last everyone is cared for, and you notice that the edge of the doorway ripples and wriggles like a reflection on water.[/p] [p]“Quick!” cries Pentegarn. “The spell is losing its power!”[/p] [p]Helping Lydia and Baltek, you hurry through the opening. The boulders grind shut behind you. You were just in time![/p]
p.next: If you choose the corridor on the right
If you choose the ledge on the left

p.text: [p]“I’m not afraid of rustling and squeaking,” says Baltek. “I say we go through this door.” He opens the door. Instantly, Owl glides off your shoulder into the room.[/p] [p]You hear tiny terrified shrieks and wild scamperings. Then Owl glides out of the darkened room and lands at your feet. A dead mouse dangles from his beak.[/p] [p]“I believe this solves the question of rustlings,” he says in a dignified tone. “Mus musculus, I believe. I don’t think it will prove to be much trouble. If you’ll excuse me, I’ll dispose of it.” Owl’s head swirls around with a quick gulp.[/p] [p]“There’s something else in the room, mouse-breath,” says Fox. “Up there near the ceiling. I can hear it, but I can’t see it.[/p] [p]Pentegarn lifts his staff and the bright white light falls upon a wriggling mass of black and brown bodies. High-pitched shrieks ring out as the creatures circle and wheel about the room.[/p] [p]“Bats! I hate bats!” screams the thief. “Why did I ever listen to you, Jaimie? We should have gone through the tunnel.”[/p]

[p]“Calm down my dear. I’ll take care of them,” says the wizard. He raises his staff once again and the creatures wheel toward the corners and away from the dazzling light. The wizard points his staff at the two largest masses of bats and two fireballs hurtle toward the ugly creatures, which then fall dead upon the ground. “You see,” says Pentegarn, “there’s nothing to worry about. You might say I have a way with animals.”[/p] [p]“Good work, Pentegarn!” says Baltek.[/p] [p]“Let’s get going,” Fox snaps impatiently.[/p] [p]“Quite right, Fox,” says the wizard. “The two doors you see before us lead to the guardroom and the alchemist’s laboratory. There may be a small amount of magic left in the alchemist’s chambers, but it’s hard to say after all these years.”[/p]
p.next: If you wish to enter the guardroom
If you wish to enter the alchemist’s chamber

p.text: [p]“Here, let me splash a little fluid of invisibility upon us,” says Pentegarn. He fumbles through his robes, searching for the container.[/p] [p]“Are you sure it’ll work?” Baltek asks anxiously.[/p] [p]“How long does it last?” Lydia asks nervously.[/p] [p]“It will work just fine,” the magic user says reassuringly. “It will last long enough for us to accomplish our mission.[/p] [p]The wizard carefully pours several drops of the liquid on the tongues of Lydia and Baltek. They disappear into thin air![/p] [p]“Not bad at all,” Lydia says gaily. The voice is directly in front of you, but you see nothing. Suddenly, invisible fingers dig into your ribs and tickle you.[/p] [p]“Stop it, stop it! I hate being tickled,” you scream. Trying to escape the persistent tickling, you roll across the dusty floor and bump into Pentegarn. You hear a tinkle and a poof. Gasping, you open your eyes and see Pentegarn wringing his hands. He looks down at the floor glumly.[/p]

[p]“I had just sprinkled Fox and Owl when you bumped me,” he frets, “I dropped the vial and it broke. Fox got a double dose and I’m afraid there’s nothing left for us.”[/p] [p]“Does that mean I’m this way forever?” yaps Fox.[/p] [p]“We could not possibly have such great fortune,” Owl says.[/p] [p]“No, it’s not permanent,” says the wizard. “But this accident might alter our plans considerably. Maybe we should go back and choose another path.”[/p]
p.next: You can go back to the secret room under the stairs and pursue another course of action
Or you can continue on this course of action and take your chances

p.text: [p]You are nearing the end of the ledge when Pentegarn halts. Suddenly Baltek draws his sword and raises it for a mighty blow. Something creeps toward you.[/p] [p]“Stop! Stop!” you shout, “It’s Fox!” A bedraggled Fox crawls out of the gloom.[/p] [p]“Hi!” he says, avoiding your eyes. “I smelled an army of skeletons coming up the trail, so I went back to take care of them. You should have seen me outwit those numbskulls! There were hundreds of them, marching up the trail one after the other, carrying battle-axes and spears. I led them on a wild-goose chase down the mountain, then circled back here! Aren’t you lucky to have me along?”[/p] [p]Pentegarn studies Fox a moment, then laughs and says, “Yes, but I hope you do not plan to leave us on our own again. In fact, your return comes at the right time. We now face a major decision.[/p] [p]“The ledge ends here. To our left a stairway leads down into the dungeons beneath the castle ruins.[/p] [p]“To our right a stairway leads directly to the tower. That way is more direct, but it will be more dangerous. What shall we do?” You may:[/p] [p class="inlineImage" data-img="86"][/p]
p.next: Take the longer route through the dungeon
Or attempt to go straight to the tower

p.text: [p]The door to the guard’s chamber proves difficult to open. Muted grating noises echo through the room; the sounds of beams and rocks shifting. You all squeeze through the door quickly and it slams shut.[/p] [p]“Quick, everyone,” shouts Lydia. “Get away from this door!”[/p] [p]Seconds later, a thick cloud of choking dust fills the room, and a loud roar shakes the floor. When the air clears, you see that the doorway is nearly buried under a mountain of dirt, rocks, and beams.[/p] [p]Taking a deep breath of relief, you examine the room by the glow of Pentegarn’s staff. Shields, swords, daggers, and other instruments of war lie about the room.[/p] [p]“Here kid, take this sword,” the fighter says, placing a weapon in your hand.[/p] [p]“I don’t know how to use this,” you say, trying to lift the heavy thing.[/p] [p]“Forget the sword, kid,” says Lydia. “Use this, I had one when I was your age.”[/p] [p]She places a small, beautiful dagger in your hand. You slide it into your belt. “I don’t know how to use this either,” you say. “But at least it’s the rightsize. What do we do now?”[/p]

[p]“We can open the door on the right and slip into the council chambers,” Pentegarn says.[/p] [p]“Where Lydia heard the rustling and scurrying,” Owl croaks.[/p] [p]“Or we can venture into the alchemist’s room,” Pentegarn says. “I seem to remember, too, that there was a door to the antechamber hidden on this side of the wall, but I can’t remember where.”[/p] [p]“Two choices are enough for me, wizard,” says the fighter. “Any more than that confuses me.”[/p]
p.next: If you wish to enter the council chambers
If you wish to enter the alchemist’s lab

p.text: [p]Pentegarn scurries about the room peering into bottles and jars. Finally, he says, “Baltek and Lydia, give me your weapons.” “What for?” Baltek asks cautiously. Pentegarn pulls an old trunk over to the work bench and rummages through it, pulling out several yards of silk scarves, a stuffed rabbit, and a vial of pink liquid. Finally, he answers Baltek, “If all goes well, I shall make your blades unbreakable and as sharp as a razor for all eternity.” “Sounds good to me,” says the fighter. “But do it quickly. I feel naked without my sword.”[/p] [p]Pentegarn pours a blue liquid onto the blades, then murmurs some magic words. Blue smoke billows over the blades. “If my memory serves me right,” Pentegarn says, “I should add a drop of Pink Oil of Permanence, and all will be done!”[/p] [p]He pours a drop on each blade, and there is a very loud poof! A streak of silvery pink shoots straight to the ceiling, staining the wizard’s beard as it passes. “Oh my, I don’t remember that,” he says.[/p] [p]He stares through the pink clouds shrouding the table. “What did I do wrong?” he asks, puzzled. “I don’t remember it smoking before.”[/p] [p]You follow his gaze down to the blades. They are pitted, crumbling, and worst of all, pink.[/p] [p class="inlineImage" data-img="90"][/p]

[p]“What have you done?” cry Baltek and Lydia angrily.[/p] [p]“That never happened before,” Pentegarn says absently. “Isn’t that amazing!”[/p] [p]“You’d better figure it out fast!” growls Baltek. “We’re easy targets for the Evil One without our weapons.”[/p] [p]“It’s quite hopeless,” Pentegarn mutters glumly. “I can’t repair these blades.” He begins rummaging through the chest at his feet again, “I’m afraid you’ll just have to settle for new ones.”[/p] [p]When he rises, he holds a set of new weapons.[/p] [p]“Feels all right to me,” Baltek says, slashing through the leg of the workbench.[/p] [p]“Since that didn’t work,” Lydia asks, sheathing her blades, “where do we go from here?”[/p] [p]“The throne room lies just beyond the next door,” answers the wizard. “It is possible he whom we seek lurks there.”[/p] [p]“Why didn’t you say so?” screeches Lydia. She tromps off toward the door.[/p] [p]“Wait!” you say, drawing the amulet from beneath your shirt, “I have to tell you something.” But no one is listening. The wizard draws himself up as tall as he can, points at the door, and whispers a magic word. The door opens.[/p]

[p]The Evil One points its staff. “Kneel before me!” it thunders.[/p] [p]With a gasp of outrage, Pentegarn flings himself at the staff.[/p] [p]“Back, back!” cries the dark voice wildly. “Bo not try!” It tries to evade Pentegarn’s rush, but Pentegarn is too fast. He reaches out and grabs the glowing staff with both hands. The dark figure tries to pull the staff back with its smoky, wispy fingers.[/p] [p]The staff turns dazzling silver, then dims to an eerie red.
